http://www.globaltrademag.com/in-the-news/the-nafta-saga-will-continue-even-after-september ". . . September 30. . . [is]  the date set out by Washington to deliver the text of a deal with or without Canada before making public (within 30-days) the text to the bilateral trade deal the United States struck with Mexico on August 30. The US administration is following the time constraints designated by the Trade Promotion Authority, also known as fast track, to ensure the agreement is subject to a straight up-or-down vote by the US Congress. Any amendments would require the negotiations to be reopened. The fast-track timing allows for a total of 90 days for consultation with Congress and stakeholders to consider the proposed agreement prior to beginning the legislative ratification process. This also coincides critically with December 1, when Mexico transitions power to its new President Andrés Manuel López Obrador. The current administrations both of Mexico and the United States would prefer to see the deal ratified by both countries in advance of Mexico’s new president taking power as there is concern from both countries that his administration could reject some of the provisions, forcing the parties back to the negotiating table. However, Canadian officials have been taking a hard line in negotiations and have stated they would rather have no deal than bind Canada to a bad deal. They also feel that the US Congress would only support a trilateral free trade deal. However, that support was called into question recently when Republican Congressman and House Whip, Steve Scalise, made a statement suggesting Congress was growing impatient with Canada’s negotiating tactics. That could be just tough talk in hopes of hastening the conclusion of negotiations that have been going on for more than a year in advance of a critical mid-term election and the initiation of a new government in Mexico. Canada hopes so, but also knows that President Donald Trump has demonstrated his willingness to staunchly uphold his negotiating positions. With the deadline upon us, the question is, what happens if Canada and the US don’t sign a deal? As has been the case throughout the NAFTA negotiations, the answer isn’t black and white. Canada could still insert itself into the bilateral deal. If no deal is reached by September 30th, there’s no reason Canada couldn’t continue to negotiate in hopes of inserting itself into the deal after that date. Speculation has emerged the Canadian delegation is loath to publicly accept a deal that most believe will contain concessions on access to the Canadian dairy market before the provincial election on October 1 in Quebec, where much of Canada’s dairy is produced. Meanwhile the text of the US-Mexico deal will be made publicly available in accordance with US law.  . . .  The US could withdraw from NAFTA. In the event no deal is reached between the US and Canada by September 30th, Washington could conceivable choose to officially withdraw from NAFTA as it puts its bilateral deal with Mexico before Congress. This would set off a six-month timeline for the termination of the agreement, during which time the US and Canada could (and likely would) continue to negotiate to either find a way to include Canada in a trilateral deal with Mexico or negotiate a separate bilateral agreement with Canada. There could be a zombie NAFTA. If Washington chooses to withdraw from NAFTA, only Congress can repeal the actual legislation associated with NAFTA. If Congress refused to do so, it would create what is often referred to as a Zombie NAFTA in which the agreement itself becomes defunct but many of the laws and provisions would continue to live on while others (such as the Chapter 19 dispute resolution mechanism) would no longer apply. That would be almost as detrimental as a Congressional approval of US withdrawal from NAFTA as cross-border investment would likely grind to a halt in response to the uncertainty around the terms of trade. However, if Congress were to approve the US-Mexico bilateral deal, it’s almost certain lawmakers would also approve a withdrawal from NAFTA as the bilateral deal would ultimately override the terms of NAFTA. The US could impose tariffs on Canadian automobile imports. The threat of a 25-percent tariff on auto imports under Section 232 of the Trade Expansion Act of 1962—the same law the US used to impose tariffs on steel and aluminum—has been repeatedly mentioned by Trump administration officials. Such a move would have one of two effects. The first is that it could generate enough bad blood between Washington and Ottawa (and Canadians and Americans) to indefinitely stall free trade negotiations in spite of the economic consequences. The second is that it would become enough of a political liability to Canada’s governing Liberal Party that it would prompt Ottawa to offer greater concessions within a revised NAFTA to hasten Canada’s inclusion in a trilateral deal. It should be noted, however, that one of the lingering issues in the NAFTA talks is that Washington won’t provide Ottawa with guarantees that it won’t impose the Section 232 tariffs on Canadian automobiles even in the event a deal is reached on NAFTA. Congress could reject the US-Mexico bilateral trade deal. Despite some recent signs of frustration and impatience, members of Congress have signalled repeatedly they would prefer a trilateral deal over a bilateral one with Mexico. In response, they could refuse to ratify the bilateral deal, ultimately forcing resumption of talks between the US and Canada. Resumption of negotiations would likely mean no deal could be reached until well into 2019 as the US would be in the midst of mid-term elections or a lame-duck Congress for the remainder of 2018 and a new Mexican administration would likely want to revisit whatever terms were agreed to by the current administration.
. . . 
. . .  the immediate period is really only another phase of negotiations that have been ongoing for more than year. September 30 will mark the end of this phase and October 1 will mark the beginning of the next phase. And we’ll know soon enough what the tone and pace of negotiations will be in that phase. The saga will almost certainly continue in one form or another.

Scenarios by which a "Yes " may occur? The most probable/foreseeable is (a) stalemate of negotiations on the Dispute Resolutions chapters of the Agreement, and (b) intervention by Executive Order before expiry of the pre-established timeline for negotiation. 
Either condition would, in normal circumstances, be highly unlikely, but these are not normal circumstances:
(a) the clauses of Chapters 4, 19 and 20 related to multilateral resolution methods were established to ensure non-abuse by a single party (the one with the strongest leverage). The US has stated that multilateral resolution processes undermine its sovereignty and removal is non-negotiable. Mexico has acquiesced. Canada has stated that multilateral resolution is mandatory to protect its interests. It will take elegant negotiation at the presidential/prime ministerial level for this to be resolved - something which I have difficulty picturing within the timeframe
(b) political pressure to reverse declining approval ratings, together with repeated declamation of the Agreement, and personal traits for action and to avoid nuance, all add to the probability of a pre-emptive Executive Order. 
Normal conditions do not apply.

NAFTA, indeed, is a withdraw-able, multinational agreement. Per Article II, Section 2 of the United States Constitution and stare decisis, no explicit wording prohibit the US president from submitting the letter of notice to withdraw from treaties (including NAFTA). However, it'd be challenging for Trump to actually complete the NAFTA withdrawal as the U.S. Constitution gives the president broad authority to negotiate treaties and conduct foreign policy while Congress shares responsibility and accountability per separation of power scheme.

COMMENT:  I think that the sages at GJ would suggest that this question lends itself to a POM analysis:  People-Objective-Motivation. People: DJT has consistently said he wants to tear up NAFTA.   We're reading that the letter to do so has been on his desk for signature more than once and was whisked away by aides, so it appears that the only constraint on him issuing a letter of notice of intent to withdraw is "patriotic" WH staffers.  Objective:  Assert himself as The Deal Maker of the Century.   DJT prides himself on being a deal-maker and negotiations are a game for him.  His modus operandi seems to be to declare everything he does a "tremendous success", so so long as it is a new deal, it will be a "tremendous success".   He seems to think, not without reason, that he is immune to public displeasure, so may have minimal concern for whatever disapproval his new deal might generate.    Therefore, I think  that there's no downside in his mind to issuing a letter of intent to withdraw  and that DJT will see it as a win no matter what happens. Motivation:  
-Assert himself as the Alpha Male over a new Mexican president (or the lame duck) and a young, photogenic Canadian PM.  
-To keep his campaign promise.
-To generate headlines.
-To create something else he did that he can claim was a "tremendous success".   Therefore, I'm not going to lower my forecast even though the time window is closing.

Mexico has signaled that they would be willing to pursue a bilateral trade agreement with the United States, but the current administration, despite this, has continued negotiations with Canada. Exiting NAFTA will economically hurt U.S. farmers and car manufacturers, and therefore I do not believe that Trump, who trumpets farmers and car manufacturers, would exit the deal. The administration will likely continue attempts to negotiate a "better deal."

My take on recent developments: - This question is actually quite specific. It will resolve as “Yes” only if one of the parties (the US?) sends to the other parties a notice containing the elements envisaged in the NAFTA treaty (e.g., invoking Article 2205) before the deadline. I presume the US administration can do this on behalf of the US (but also see the useful comments of @Emil ), but for the moment they have declared no intention of doing so (see the comments of @pietrokc).   - if the above is not done, any other action of the US administration seems irrelevant to the question. Sending a notification of a new treaty to Congress (as they did on August 31) or even sending the actual text of a US-Mexico treaty by end-September does not resolve the question as a “Yes”. While it may well create confusion in Congress, in principle it is legally possible for the US to have two treaties with Mexico (and Canada), as long as it is clear which one has precedence in case of conflict.   - on the substance, think about it: NAFTA contains a few thousand pages of detailed provisions. What we know about the US-Mexico agreement is that it concerns a relatively limited number of issues that modify some (but far from all) of the original NAFTA provisions. So either the US-Mexico agreement copies and pastes the unmodified parts (in which case, it would amount to a modified NAFTA), or simply states that the unmodified parts remain effective (in which case it modifies, but does not repeal NAFTA). Either way, large parts of NAFTA remain in place, unless specifically repealed.   - can the US administration actually give notice in line with NAFTA procedures? This is certainly possible, but unlikely. Again, the issue is the unmodified parts of NAFTA - they have to be either repealed (unpopular with business groups) or incorporated in the new treaty (which may slow Congress’ approval given the size of the document). Beside, why would the administration bother - for them it is sufficient to announce that NAFTA is effectively dead (as Trump has) without incurring the economic and legal costs of actually repealing it.

Lowering further as I understand that there is some legal uncertainty as to whether Trump can unilaterally sent a notice letter to withdraw. Originally, I had assumed it as a certainty after reading [1] but I was digging more today and from [2] and [3] it seems that Trump probably has that authority but not all legal experts agree.  Specifically, [2] writes: "There is no provision in the Implementation Act [the U.S. law that implements NAFTA] that empowers the president or any office of the administration to give a notice of withdrawal under NAFTA Article 2205, let alone effecting the withdrawal of the US government from NAFTA." Article 2205 of NAFTA is up for interpretation: "“A Party may withdraw from this Agreement six months after it provides written notice of withdrawal to the other Parties. If a Party withdraws, the Agreement shall remain in force for the remaining Parties.” This means that, 1) I am incorporating that uncertainty in my forecast and 2) incorporating the fact that the administration will face legal challenges if it tried to provide notice to withdraw, which makes it ever so slightly less likely to try it. Revising closer to 50 percent (from 64).  I think there is a non-negligible chance of maintaining NAFTA and re-branding/re-naming it informally or formally to appease Trump. Trump's Orwellian skills and the megaphone provided by sympathetic media outlets could be enough to make his base believe that "this is not NAFTA, it's something completely different" and be able to claim a major victory.  Otherwise a complete re-working of NAFTA might involve too many hurdles. It's not just rewriting it. There are also two political factors. First, Congress gave specific approval/mandate for Trump to renegotiate NAFTA. I see it as slightly unlikely (~40%) that Republicans will go along with a bilateral deal, which large businesses seem opposed to. Much of it comes down Trump's ability to ram things through Congress. Since primaries are done, Republicans will not be threatened by Trump-aligned challengers and have more latitude to stand up to him. Second, if NAFTA is scrapped, there is uncertainty as to whether that would open up agenda items that were previously not up for discussion. Creating a new agreement from scratch might cause Canada (and maybe Mexico though they are likely to be reluctant to endanger the current agreement) to demand further changes. Canada does have some leverage when it comes to timing because Trump would like to bring a deal to Congress in time to have it done before the midterms. Alternatively, the three countries might agree to copy-paste 95% of NAFTA, take the negotiated changes and sign a whole new treaty but that just seems like an unnecessary hassle (see first paragraph above).  However, it is still possible for the administration to sent a letter of intent to withdraw simply as a threat, which is why I am on the "probable" side of maybe.

The NAFTA talks have been stalled, making it all but impossible for them to conclude before the midterm elections in November — when Trump faces the real danger that Republicans could lose the House majority. Several major sticking points have slowed talks, including disagreements about whether to include a sunset clause, rules of origin on products such as automobiles and the use of an international dispute settlement mechanism when problems arise. Trump’s threat to impose new auto tariffs has the potential to destabilize new talks. Adding a new 25 percent import tax on Mexican-built cars could explode the discussions on rules of origin, which lay out how much of a car can be built in Mexico or Canada to qualify for sale in the U.S. under NAFTA. Trump directed the Commerce Department to look into the issue and could act as soon as it issues a report, potentially as early as September. Another potentially important factor is López Obrador and Trump’s personal chemistry.
. . . 
On that front, initial signs are positive. Trump spent a half-hour on the phone with López Obrador on Monday and told reporters afterward that the conversation went well. S&P Global predicted that, despite hiccups, a new deal would eventually get signed. Even if negotiations to renew NAFTA fall apart, however, scrapping the trade arrangement altogether remains a distant prospect. That would require Trump to formally withdraw from the treaty, plus congressional action to undo NAFTA-related legislation.
~~~~~~~

https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-05-14/here-s-why-trump-is-looking-to-seal-a-new-nafta-deal-soon May 14, 2018  When he started negotiations on a new North American Free Trade Agreement last year, President Donald Trump invoked a legislative process called trade-promotion authority, a measure to ease the passage of trade deals by Congress. It allows him to seek a simple yes-or-no vote by lawmakers on an updated pact with Mexico and Canada. In exchange, the administration must clear a series of steps designed to build support among politicians.
. . . 
Here are some steps that must be taken for Congress to approve a trade deal under fast-track authority: The administration must give Congress 90 days’ notification that it plans to sign a deal Once the deal is signed, the U.S. International Trade Commission has 105 days to produce a report on the economic impact The Senate Finance and House Ways and Means committees will likely hold hearings and suggest tweaks, known as “markups” After an implementing bill is introduced in the Senate and House, both chambers can take up to 90 days to debate it Talk of putting a new Nafta to a vote in Congress assumes the three countries can even reach an agreement, which is by no means a given. In recent weeks, the three sides have been aiming for a “deal-in-principle.” None of the countries have clarified what that means, but trade experts speculate it would entail a consensus on the most contentious issues, such as rules for how to count the origin of car parts that qualify for duty-free treatment. Such a deal would be a long way from a formal text that lawmakers can vote on. The wild card is Trump’s threat to withdraw from the original Nafta. Under the pact, any of the three countries can pull out on six-months’ notice. If the president wants to light a fire under Congress, he could sign a withdrawal notice after negotiating an update he likes. That would give legislators a hard six-moth deadline to agree to the updated trade pact. In other words, lawmakers would have to accept Trump’s Nafta, or none at all.

Outside view: NAFTA has existed since 1994. In general, countries rarely withdraw from trade agreements, though it's probably happened in the past. I wish I had data on this but for now it's a qualitative judgment. Trade is generally good for the economy and any leader who withdraws from a major trade agreement will likely suffer politically (note that Brexit is not really in the same category as it is not only a withdrawal from the common market but withdrawal from EU directives and sphere of influence which is more what Britons wanted I think). This makes a withdrawal rather unlikely. Inside view lowers the odds further in my opinion: Withdrawing from NAFTA will likely deal a significant economic blow to the U.S. Though U.S. has a trade deficit with Canada and Mexico, it still exports large amount of goods produced by politically powerful sectors (https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2017/business/nafta-canada-mexico.html, https://www.reuters.com/article/us-trump-effect-nafta-farmers/u-s-farmers-have-much-to-lose-if-nafta-deal-collapses-idUSKBN1FH0O0).  More importantly, Canada and Mexico have shown at least some willingness to negotiate, and the administration seems to want to finalize the current talks according to NYT: https://www.nytimes.com/2018/05/06/business/nafta-disney-fox.html?emc=edit_nn_20180507&nl=morning-briefing&nlid=7394822120180507&te=1, see also this for where the negotiations stand: https://www.reuters.com/article/us-trade-nafta/nafta-talks-enter-critical-week-with-u-s-pushing-hard-line-idUSKBN1I80BK This points toward some kind of a resolution that appeases Trump, while keeping the U.S. in.

But the pace of NAFTA negotiations has accelerated in the past few weeks. Canada’s chief negotiator, Minister of Foreign Affairs Chrystia Freeland, said in late April that talks were in an intensive stage, with technical teams working long hours and weekends to get a deal done. Still, Trump has expressed little urgency to reach an agreement and said last week he wasn’t sure a quick deal would be in America’s interests. In the normal course of things, new NAFTA would be put to a vote in Congress, which would in effect be choosing between old NAFTA and new NAFTA. WH seems scared new NAFTA might not win. By withdrawing, Congress would in effect be voting on new NAFTA or no NAFTA at all. One problem I see with this strategy is that Congress can simply vote to bring old NAFTA back, even after WH withdraws --- right? Or more precisely, they can vote to override the notice of withdrawal. Also, given the extensive news coverage of what's going on with NAFTA --- and the recent repeated headlines of people saying negotiations are going well --- it seems to me that the withdraw-to-get-vote move would be relatively transparent to the public. Then it might be relatively easy to paint Trump as a dictator trying to take choice away from Congress. I guess previous paragraph assumes public is paying attention to these developments. (I've been googling nafta news almost every day for weeks so I'm biased.) Let's look at people who could barely say what NAFTA is, much less what's happening with it. They may have heard one or two headlines that NAFTA negotiations are going well. Then Trump comes on TV and says he's pulling out of NAFTA --- presumably with some kind of speech about how NAFTA is bad, because he can't just come out and say he's doing it to get the vote he wants. Plus he is Trump so he can't just say NAFTA is kind of bad --- he's going to say it's the worst thing since original sin. Then a few weeks or months later he rejoins NAFTA. (It can't be that long because business will get jitters.) Isn't that weird, even to the uninformed person? Finally, even assuming they are willing to go through with all this, the act of publicizing this strategy puts Congress on notice, which lets negotiations ensue --- either Congress believes WH threats and caves before the move needs to be pulled, or WH believes Congress threats and doesn't pull move. (up 5). Now that it's clear that Canada and Mexico are excluded from the steel & aluminum tariffs, let's think what might be the impact of the tariff saga on the outcome of this question. Trump threatened to impose these tariffs on the US NAFTA partners if no NAFTA deal to his liking is reached - and then backed off. How to read this? On the one hand, Trump did show that he is willing to break - or at least make more costly - established free-trade links. On the other hand, he backed off somewhat under pressure from free-trade Republicans. One way to read this is that Mexico and Canada have to show some more flexibility in the NAFTA talks - to give Trump some victories to ward off bigger disasters. If they go this way, the chance of a notice to withdraw declines. On the other hand, Mexico and Canada may feel emboldened by the support they received from most of the American political class in the tariff discussion and refuse to give in on the substantial issues. This would increase the chance of a notice - as a pressure instrument if nothing more. On the third hand, Trump showed once again his negotiating tactics - throw a big bomb first, alarm everybody, and then scale down the actual policy action. It's not inconceivable he may do the same with a notice to withdraw. But timing would be important here - if it's clear that the NAFTA talks cannot be finished on the original schedule and have to continue after the Mexican elections, will Trump issue the notice before the talks are finished? I think not - such a notice is not a vote-gainer for the Republican party overall (it may energize the anti-trade base, but will repel the business groups, and many Democrats are anti-trade as well). On balance, I still think the most likely scenario is that NAFTA talks continue through October 1 (and probably into 2019, after the new Mexican administration gets into office on Dec 1). But there is a chance that a notice is issued before the deadline, and this chance seems slightly larger than before the tariff episode.

The question asks if "the U.S. will provide notice of intent to withdraw".  This is a very specific and largely ceremonial action with little real consequence and is squarely within the President's power; seems like just the type of move Trump could pull for political purposes closer to the fall midterm elections.  He could also provide a notice of intent to use as a negotiation tool in an attempt to re-negotiate the agreement.  Many other forecasters' comments show they are trying to answer the question "will the US actually formally withdraw from NAFTA" (not just provide intent).  There is also the legislation 'NAFTA Implementation Act' that actually implements all the stipulations that keep US commerce in line with the agreement (so, even if the executive branch technically withdrawls the US, it would have no real impact unless Congress changes the law). There seems to be much confusion about these technicalities in most media reports, but I think understanding these differences increases the chance the President will give this a shot as a negotiation/political tool.

This week, the sixth round of renegotiation talks for the North American Free Trade Agreement is scheduled to take place in Montreal, Canada. In the lead-up, both trade observers and markets careened from despair to relief as they assessed and reassessed NAFTA’s prospects.
Two weeks ago, Mexico’s currency weakened and some U.S. trade-related stocks fell on a report that Canada was increasingly convinced President Donald Trump would pull the United States out of NAFTA. On closer examination, it was not clear there was anything particularly novel in the report and the Canadian government denied holding such pessimistic views, but the episode demonstrated the deep-seated concern among investors watching closely.
For optimists, there were reassurances from Republican U.S. Senators to the contrary. Pat Roberts (R-KS), Chairman of the Senate Committee of Agriculture, said of the President, “I think he's seeing the big picture a lot better and the possible detrimental situation of what would occur if in fact he would terminate NAFTA.”
Politics. It is relatively easy to argue that NAFTA withdrawal would be a political disaster for the President. It would hit at many red states that are dependent on farm exports and form the core of his political support. It would also hit at the auto sector, disproportionately affecting states like Michigan. And some recent market wobbles suggest that there is at least a chance that the move could undermine the business optimism that has helped propel the stock market to lofty Yet what matters is the President’s perception of the politics, and he sees antipathy to trade as central to his appeal to his base. NAFTA’s fate may depend on how compelled he feels to fire up that base.

Trump made withdrawing from NAFTA a central plank of his campaign, but despite the rhetoric his administration has yet to take any definitive step toward withdrawal. Considering the potential opposition in Congress to withdrawing from NAFTA and Trump's tendency to give in to demands of the more establishment-oriented, "globalist" elements in his administration, it is unlikely that the US would pull out of NAFTA by October.

A complete withdrawal would be a colossal failure for Trump's campaign promise to "get America better deals", negotiations will continue, and any complete failure would be stalled until after the midterms.

The threat of pulling out of NAFTA is more valuable than actually carrying it out. Keeping the possibility alive gains the Trump administration some ammunition or leverage it can use in other negotiations with Canada and Mexico, and even China. In addition, the midterm elections are coming, and American exports of food and raw materials to its neighbors largely come from "red states". Derailing their economies before an election would be unwise.
Intent maybe, but it wont happen.
The threat is more useful than the act

While the Trump administration has often bashed NAFTA and this could continue to escalate, it remains unlikely that they will withdraw by October 2018. The conservative orthodoxy does not currently support withdrawal from NAFTA. Withdrawing from this trade agreement right before midterm elections would give more ammunition to Democrats to paint the GOP as hostile to business and competitiveness, and it seems likely that McConnell and Ryan would pressure the executive branch not to make any moves.  While the withdrawal from the TPP could be perceived as evidence that the Trump administration will withdraw from further agreements, I find the opposite to be true. The TPP had not been signed yet, and they can present that to their base as evidence that they are anti-trade. Further moves to threaten trade agreements however would result in considerably more blowback as NAFTA has been a stable agreement for decades and any negative consequences would immediately result in punishing headlines. In addition, making minor changes to NAFTA would allow the Trump administration to continue the narrative that they are pro-American without dissolving the agreement. If the perceived Democratic wave never materializes, I believe it will embolden the administration and the probability of a withdrawal would rise, but under the current circumstances, even given Trump's volatility, I find this unlikely.

There currently appears to be a poor probability of a successful outcome in the negotiations.  Trump's behaviour in light of an impasse will likely be governed by prevailing short-term circumstances at the relevant time, his instinct as to how his decision will be viewed by various constituencies and subject to exaggerated influence by his advisors.  Reason will likely have little impact.  Considering a pessimistic view of the outcome of negotiations and Trump's predilection to throw the cat among the pidgeons, I think that termination is more likely than not.

(down 10) First, as I expected, Trump hinted at willingness to continue the NAFTA talks after the end of the scheduled rounds in March, and perhaps even after the Mexican elections on July 1. Mexico and Canada strongly welcomed the hint. This means that the window for serving a notice before Oct 1 is shrinking. (One complication: the next Mexican administration would assume office only on December 1. I don't think the US would want to wait that long, so talks will probably resume before that - not sure how productive they will be before Dec 1). Second, Mexico has indicated some willingness to move toward the US proposals. Specifically, they have proposed that NAFTA is reviewed and revised every 5 years (the US wants automatic termination every 5 years unless the parties agree to extend NAFTA). Regarding the rules of origin in the auto industry (another controversial issue), Mexico can agree to some increase in the regional (North American) content in cars' value from the current 62.5%, although they still think the US-proposed 85% (of which 50 percentage point US content) is unrealistically high. This means that the Jan/Mar talks are likely to be assessed as productive, reducing the probability of a notice.  

To summarize, I expect the parties to make some progress in the January and March rounds and make encouraging public noises about them, enough for all to convince their domestic constituencies that things are moving in the right direction. Discussions will then resume in late summer/early fall, with an agreement expected in 2019.  What can go wrong with this forecast:
 - First, Mexico may find it hard to show willingness to compromise before the elections. The government candidate for President is a distant third in the opinion polls, and any perception of softness toward the US may not help; 
 - Second, if not much progress is made by March, the US may revisit the idea of providing notice as a negotiation tool. If they are going this route, I think they are more likely to do this after the Mexican elections, but this could still be before Oct 1.

An update:
 - Two more rounds of scheduled negotiations remain: Jan 23-28 and late March. The positions of the US on the one hand and Mexico-Canada on another remain far apart on the substantive issues (rules of origin and sunset clauses forcing automatic renegotiations every five years).

 - I think it's highly unlikely that an agreement can be reached by end-March. The US administration then will face a choice between the following options: (1) continue to negotiate after the Mexican elections (July 1) - by far the more likely outcome in my view, especially if Mexico and Canada have shown some flexibility in the Jan-Mar rounds. This keeps all options open without alienating influential pro-NAFTA Republican constituencies. And, for Trump, 2020 is a more important date than 2018 to show that he keeps his promises (assuming he wants to run again). In this case, it's nearly impossible to conclude the new rounds of discussions by Oct 1 - at most, there could be one more round in September, not enough for anything;  (2) Declare the negotiations failed, in which case a notice of intent to withdraw is a must - otherwise, the administration would lose both face and credibility. The notice can also be used as a negotiation device, as others have noted. But to be successful, it needs to be credible, and the timing is a problem here - given the Mexican and the US elections, not much can be accomplished in the 6-month window of the notice, even if the notice itself is delayed by, say, June 2018. But I give this scenario a non-zero probability for two reasons:
(i) May be the notice can be issued as late as September 2018 - in the eve of renewed negotiations, or after a first (unsuccessful) round. Then there would be enough time, more or less. A risky strategy, but not out of question;
(ii) An intriguing possibility discussed in a Bloomberg article from Dec 15 (can be easily Googled) is that the administration serves the notice, but Congress does not agree (or just does not raise the import tariffs on Mexico and Canada). This may happen even with the tacit agreement of the administration, again as a tool to apply pressure on Mexico and Canada. The US may view this as having their cake and eating it too - not immediately hurting US businesses benefitting from NAFTA while forcing Mexico and Canada to compromises. Of course, the resulting uncertainty will harm businesses' medium-term plans, but the administration may be gambling that the negotiations can then be closed in a few months.

Three probability estimates govern my forecast:
 - the probability that NAFTA renegotiations will be completed before Oct 1 (I assign 20% here, as the Mexican elections in July will intervene - see my earlier post. May even reduce it further the next time);
 - the probability that the renegotiations will fail. Here I reduce my probability estimate from 75% to 60%. The US has quite a leverage over both Mexico and Canada, being the largest - by far - trading partner for both, so it's not inconceivable that some sort of an agreement can be reached, especially if the US negotiators moderate their demands a little. It's still less likely than 50/50, though. 
 - the probability that a notice will be provided if renegotiations fail. Here I keep 100%, as (i) if negotiations are allowed to fail (as opposed to being extended), this would mean that Trump has given up on an agreement; and (ii) if there is no chance of an agreement, Trump can't afford to do nothing - he would lose both face and credibility with his base.  So my estimate of the probability of an "yes" drops to 12% now (0.2*0.6*1).
